newsitem.title: USA: Dollar sinks on late profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Dollar sinks on late profit-taking.

text.p: The dollar ended lower against major currencies Tuesday as a late afternoon nosedive wiped out modest early gains.
Investors sold the dollar and British pound against the mark to lock in profits after several days of rallying, while a wire service report triggered dollar sales for yen, currency dealers said.
Market News Service reported that an unidentified White House official predicted the persistent trade gap between the United States and Japan would soon begin to widen after months of shrinkage.
When U.S. imports from Japan exceed exports to Japan, Japanese firms are left with a steady supply of extra dollars that must be sold in the foreign exchange market.
"That story is probably what got the ball rolling," said James Phoenix, director of foreign exchange sales at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce in New York.
For most of the session the dollar had hovered just below Tuesday's 33-month high at 112.91 yen. But the late selloff left the dollar at 112.27 yen, down from 112.72 late Monday.

Against the mark, the dollar fell nearly a pfennig to 1.5248 from 1.5343 late Monday. The dollar also fell to 1.2535 Swiss francs from 1.2630. The British pound ended higher at $1.5982 from $1.5926. The dollar fell to Canadian $1.3449 from C$1.3466.
Investors sold sterling when it failed to top key technical levels at 2.45 marks, a 22-month high, and $1.60. The mark and Swiss franc powered higher against the dollar as a result, dealers said.

"We saw some pretty aggressive dollar selling by investment banks. Some people had (bought) the dollar in the morning, but when there was no follow-through buying, they got nervous," said Stephen Jury, chief dealer at Union Bank of Switzerland in New York.

The dollar climbed against the yen in early trading after Japan reported its index of leading economic indicators plunged to 33.3 in August from 77.8 in July -- well below the 50.0 level deemed the boundary between boom and bust.
That suggests the Bank of Japan will keep interest rates low in coming months, which would bolster the dollar by enhancing the relative value of assets priced in dollars.

"The Japanese economy is still struggling. The dollar should continue to move gradually higher against the yen over the next month or so," said Tadatoshi Taso, chief dealer at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York.
The mark also got an early boost as Germany kicked off a campaign to sell its state-owned telephone company, Deutsche Telekom.
The proposed sale would raise about 18 billion marks and investors speculated the mark would rise as a result of the temporary increase in demand for the German unit.
"Today's move was very much a move of the mark against sterling and the yen. That also touched off some sales of dollars for marks," said Chris Adair, currency trader at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
